reviewText:
Raywin is a 8-bit JRPG. The story focuses around the main protagonist Raywin who, because of prophecy, has to go off to fight in the war of Salemsun and save the kingdom.

The main story is quite simple and the side quests are even simplier (go there, take that and bring it to somebody)

Items don't tell you what they do neither what is its purpose in the game. You can't sell them in the stores too.

The map is full of empty space and empty of life. There are only two npc if you need to talk to them and some decoration.

Where are monsters? I've defeated five or six monsters in the game and I haven't seen their hit points or their heal/attack statistics on the screen.

The game has a level system but you won't use it quite often because the character will level from level one to level two.

There are glitches everywhere, for example in the first room near the clock, you can walk across the wall.

The character is easy to control using four arrows and spacebar.

Graphics, music and sound are quite normal.

Unfortunatelly, this game seems more a test project of RPGMaker than a finished game

Maybe this is the first work of the developer but it needs too much work and better quality assurance.

It has achivements and trading cards

The best thing I could tell about the game is that you will finish it in an hour and will obtain all the achivements, so you are going to have a completed game in your library without any effort.

Sorry, but I don't recommend it.

PD: Thanks to Shade00
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When I bought Raywin I knew it wasn't going to be innovative, but what I didn't expect was the amount of bugs and glitches this game would include.

The Good:
-The menu system works well.
-Some of the monsters you fight look cool.

The Bad:
- Lazy house and building design.
-Doors that are attached to air
-Lifeless NPCs
-Linear story
-Game breaking bugs littered throughout the game.

My Score:
1/5

reviewText:
Well first let me start by saying that this game cost me $2.
That being said as an aspiring casual game developer who is interested in making games as a hobby, I am glad that I purchased this game so I could see exactly what not to do.

I know that this must have taken the developer a good deal of time to make regardless of how awful it turned out, so I won't even ask for a refund, keep the $2 I'd say you earned it. People get a lot more for less begging on the streets and holding up a sign so I'm not going to complain about $2. Also, You can take this positive review because I understand that even though the game was one of the worst I've ever played, it took you time to make it.

Some of the issues wrong with this game are pretty much 100% everything that everybody else who left a negative review on it already stated as well as some other gamebreaking bugs. I got 75% through the game and had to start over because I purchased a weapon and didn't have enough money to purchase a goblin suit to get past the guards. The vendor also would not let me sell any of the items I had picked up throughout the game so I had no way of earning the money and was forced to start over.

Overall the game took about 40 minutes to complete from start to finish while reading all of the dialogue and exploring unnecessary areas.

Definitely a game that shouldn't have been on steam, it isn't finished but I'm glad you posted it as a learning lesson for both you and I. I got some positive information out of the game and it was worth my $2 so thank you, I appreciate it.

I recommend this game if anyone wants to have a good laugh and enjoys playing terrible games, or if they plan on making their own games and want to see what an epic dumpsterfire looks like.

I feel like an awful person leaving negative feedback on this game, but in all honesty I'd say its warrented for releasing a product like this for sale.

I look forward to playing Raywin 2.

1/10 would play again.
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'm probably one of the first to finish the game. It took me a while longer than it should have because I had to contact the dev to figure out a bug. A regular play through would probably take 45 minutes at the most. First things first, the dev is very helpful and great. Unfortunately the game has a ways to go before it's worth buying.

There are some glaring problems, and I'll try to make this review as constructive as possible so hopefully Raywin 2 addresses these problems.

1. There is no tutorial to learn the controls. They are easy enough but you first need to try all your keys to see if they do anything.

2. Items don't tell you what they do. You have a healing potion? Great! But it doesn't tell you how much it will heal you. Vegatables? Fun! What are they even used for? I didn't use an item throughout the entire game.

3. You can't see the HP of the enemy. How am I supposed to know when to heal/attack? So far I just attack and eventually win, and have some NPC heal me. Not much strategy.

4. Wall/noclip glitches everywhere. Doesn't feel like a complete game. Not to mention, 95% of every shop screen is empty space. There is no decoration, and on the off-chance there is decoration, half the time you can walk right through it.

5. Can't go back to places already visited. Found that out too late, so I think I missed some content.

6. The quests" are as simple as "walk 5 spaces and click 'space' 8 times then come back". Another quest you literally turn into a rock
recommended: to sneak by some guards. That's the only time you turn into a rock in the whole game. I would understand if it the game was introducing a new mechanic
hoursPlayed: but it's not. I just don't get it.\n\nOne nice part about the game is the leveling system. It seems really cool
voteText: but since you only defeat maybe 5 enemies (you can avoid the rest without problem) you don't really get to try it out. At the end
helpfulPercent: each of my characters levelled one.. to level 2. I feel like this would have been a fun part of the game
votesHelpful: I just wish I was able to take advantage of it!\n\nOverall
votesTotal: not a very gripping game. Needs a lot of work fixing some bugs. I don't recommend it in its current state.\n\n**To get into the museum
votesFunny: you need to press space to enter. This is a confirmed bug so may not be relevant if the dev fixes the bug before you read this review."
column18: 84 of 95 people (88%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
o_O

I don't even know how to start... This is a RPGMaker test that got greenlit and it's bad, really really bad. It's a collection of random half-done screens with lots of collision errors. The main plot takes about 40 minutes and consists of the most cringe worthy lines ever written. The combat system is hilariously bad and special attacks don't inflict any more damage than the bog standard one. There's really nothing here except for six achievements and a perfect game.

Still, it is so bad that I laughed really hard, so you might just get it for that.
voteText: 30 of 36 people (83%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Look, I like what you are trying to do, and I enjoyed an RPG that didn't take long to beat.

The story is nothing more than a series of events, obviously constructed as a basic first game.

Many blatant spelling errors, problematic controls, graphical errors and so many glitches.

If you went through and corrected all of your mistakes, you could at least consider it a 99 cent episodic RPG.

As is, you are selling a broken game with no real point.

I bought the last weapons you can purchase in the game, and they are not even stronger.  You get the katana and can't even use it, inventory items with no purpose.  I never used a single thing beyond the item needed for the quest.

I think this is not retailable content.  I rarely say a game is a thumbs down, this is not really a game.  You are selling your test project, unfinished and sloppy.  IMO this is unprofessional, and you could probably do better.

No trolling, just trying to give honest feedback.

reviewText:
The key for this game was indirectly given to me by the developer for review purposes but it will not change the tone of my review

Raywin is a 2D JRPG made on RPG Maker. Just as the name of the game suggests, the story is focused on the hero Raywin who according to a prophecy must defeat Salemsun. The game is just bad even if it is the first game that the developers made and this is supported by the fact that one of the game's selling points is having ‚òÖ Over 40 items" which isn't even that much compared to other RPG Maker games. Let me start of by saying the game is incredibly short and overall not a fun experience.

Where do I start with the flaws of this game.... First of all the game has tons of nonclip/wall glitches and bugs

reviewText:
Oh and then? A buggy Game.
This game was created with RPG Maker and it actually is a good example why this tool is so often disregarded as a creator tool that isn't for creating good games.

A lot of games created with RPG Maker are good games, they have a good story, a perfect match of balance and characterbuilding... But this? Well, it's a debut - so I won't be too hard. But even for a debut it could have been a lot more, not just a ragtag bag of mixed apples, peaches, pears and juice...

And again - the chosen 1000000000000 Take... sigh.

The bugs in the game are uterly frustrating and at times gamebreaking. Suddenly you have an Map-Call for a Map that doesn't exit.

Pro:It's real short, so your frustration might not rise as high as it would be justified. That's at least good for the blood pressure.Con:No story, at least not a really decent one.
Buggy and often crashing... Not beta tested at all.
Bad balancing, no challenge and therefore no strategies required.
It's too expensive!
No Recommendation
The game is too buggy, too half-baked to have a value for any player. You can get free games on the Workshop for RPG-Maker that were a lot more thought about, a lot more of programming was put in and then you have this...

I just don't know why anyone should bother to buy this game? Well, I got it in a bundle - or so... and I opted to try it out... It was a bad idea to do so.

reviewText: Well the game isn't that good as it looks at first sight. The story is short. The music is not bad. The game visuals are good, but I don't like that the characters faces near chat log is made with cgi. When I usually play this kind of games I like that everything is pixelated. When fighting enemies, it would be nice to see how much health they have. Also there are a few bugs that could be fixed (like going into the wall). In overall this game could be better, but it isn't.
voteText: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I hate to put a negative review, as I know how hard it can be to make a videogame. Even when not from scratch it is still very time consuming and thinking of an original story these days just isn't easy in the slightest. Unfortunately this game just isn't good. It is obvious instantly that this is made with RPG Maker pre-made assets. You can tell this from the way the sprite look in-game to how their psuedo-3D faces look when dialogue options come up. There are tons of grammatical errors and really cringey and cliche writing. The game is a very cheap price and for that I think it would be a good purchase if you're planning on making games and want to see what others have done for a cheap price.

reviewText: If you plan to get into making RPG Maker games, this is a great example of MANY things you should not do. The most obvious being, don't sell your first project because it will be terrible. Disclaimer, I got this for free, and since I would need to idle it longer than the playtime to get the cards, I figured I would give a go since I heard it was about 45 minutes long.\n\nHere is a brief idea of why it is terrible. The pointless items, the nearly nonexistent plot, noclip and other bugs, bland almost empty maps, and that ending?! Yeah... I am looking forward to Raywin 2........

reviewText:
Well first let me start by saying that this game cost me $2.
That being said as an aspiring casual game developer who is interested in making games as a hobby, I am glad that I purchased this game so I could see exactly what not to do.

I know that this must have taken the developer a good deal of time to make regardless of how awful it turned out, so I won't even ask for a refund, keep the $2 I'd say you earned it. People get a lot more for less begging on the streets and holding up a sign so I'm not going to complain about $2. Also, You can take this positive review because I understand that even though the game was one of the worst I've ever played, it took you time to make it.

Some of the issues wrong with this game are pretty much 100% everything that everybody else who left a negative review on it already stated as well as some other gamebreaking bugs. I got 75% through the game and had to start over because I purchased a weapon and didn't have enough money to purchase a goblin suit to get past the guards. The vendor also would not let me sell any of the items I had picked up throughout the game so I had no way of earning the money and was forced to start over.

Overall the game took about 40 minutes to complete from start to finish while reading all of the dialogue and exploring unnecessary areas.

Definitely a game that shouldn't have been on steam, it isn't finished but I'm glad you posted it as a learning lesson for both you and I. I got some positive information out of the game and it was worth my $2 so thank you, I appreciate it.

I recommend this game if anyone wants to have a good laugh and enjoys playing terrible games, or if they plan on making their own games and want to see what an epic dumpsterfire looks like.

I feel like an awful person leaving negative feedback on this game, but in all honesty I'd say its warrented for releasing a product like this for sale.

I look forward to playing Raywin 2.

1/10 would play again.
voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Easy game, like Assassin's Creed, just spam X to win, never needed to equip anything other than quest items.
Took me about exactly 1 hour to beat the game and get all the achievements (all 6 of them at least). It also has cards.

Obviously the game was a start up for a younger kid/developer it seems?
It shows, but again, this is better than most indie games currently releasing.

This has a story, menu system, you can level up and learn new abilites, every NPC is actually involved in some way as well. Add in the fact that the dev actually put in achievements and cards and this surpasses most of the BS lazy devs on steam.

The Assassin Creed series (all of them) has no Steam features, but this does, let that sink in.

Game has a horrible ending though, is cheesy cliffhanger that sets up the sequel.

+1 dev listens/responds.
Would rec the game because of the work that went into it, from what it seems, was a one man show.

reviewText: Oh my god what a mess! Not only is this game extremely blatant with its RPG Maker mold, but this has got to be some of the most ridiculous NPC character (or lack of) and dialogue I've seen in the genre. It's laughably bad, but that is by no means a reason why you should pay actual money for something like this. In fact, for a game that's an RPG, it doesn't even last an hour. Maybe if it was a GOOD hour, I'd give it credit, but instead it's been filled up with walking around dull locations fetching this and that and going to here for a scripted sequence. I can't say anything in-depth about the battles because there's NO WAY to lose them! You can automatically spam the same attack and win every battle.\n\nAnd then this game had the nerve, the AUDACITY, to make a sequel hook. Not only that, but it closes the game RIGHT BEFORE Raywin could face the final boss, so therefore there's no final boss in this game. My god, what a mess.
